Skt. brahmacarya-parivarta
At that time, King Ajatashatru of Rajagriha was by nature evil and enjoyed killing, possessing the four evils of speech, greed, anger, and ignorance.

His mind was rampant, only seeing the present and not the future, and was surrounded by evil people.ğŸ”½Because of greed for the pleasures of the five desires in the present world, he unjustly killed his innocent father, the king.
After killing his father, he felt remorse and his body was covered in sores, the stench of which was unbearable.
He thought to himself:
My body has already received the flower retribution, and the retribution of hell is not far away.
At that time, his mother, named VaidehÄ«, applied various medicines to the wound, but it continued to worsen and did not improve.
The king then said to his mother:
This wound arises from the mind and is not caused by the four elements.
If you say there is a being who can cure it, that is impossible.
At that time, there was a great minister named Candra who went to where the king was, stood to one side, and said:
Great king!
Why are you so sorrowful and your countenance not pleasant?
Is it a pain in the body?
Or a pain in the mind?
The king replied to the minister:
How could my body and mind not be in pain now?
My father was innocent, yet I committed the crime of patricide.
I have heard this meaning from the wise:
'There are five kinds of people in the world who cannot escape hell, namely those who commit the five heinous crimes.'
I now have immeasurable, limitless, incalculable sins. How can my body and mind not be in pain?
Moreover, there is no good doctor to treat my body and mind.
The minister said:
Great King!
Do not be greatly sorrowful.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
If one always grieves, grief will only increase;
Just as one who delights in sleep will have more and more sleep;
So it is with greed, lust, and drinking alcohol.
As the king said:
'In the world, there are five people who cannot escape hell.'
Who went to see them and told the king?
Speaking of hell, it is simply what the wise ones in the world say.
As the king said:
'In the world, there is no good doctor to treat body and mind.'

There is now a great physician named Purana, who knows everything and sees everything, has attained mastery over concentration, and has always practiced pure celibacy for countless beings, expounding the path to the unsurpassed nirvana.
He teaches his disciples the Dharma like this:

There are no black actions, no retribution for black actions, no white actions, no retribution for white actions, no black and white actions, no retribution for black and white actions, no superior actions, and no inferior actions.
This teacher is now in Rajagriha. I only wish that the great king would go there and have this teacher cure his body and mind.
Then the king replied:
If he can indeed eliminate my sins like this, I will take refuge in him.
There was another minister named Nidhi, who went to the king and said:
Great King!
Why is your face haggard, your lips dry, and your voice so faint, like a timid person seeing a great enemy, your complexion changed?
What is your suffering?
Is it a pain in the body?
Or a pain in the heart?
The king then replied:
How can my body and mind not be in pain?

I am foolish and blind, lacking the eyes of wisdom. I have recently associated with evil friends as good people and followed the words of the evil Devadatta. I have committed the heinous crime of killing a righteous king.
I once heard a wise person speak a verse:ğŸ”½'If one gives rise to an unwholesome mind
And commits evil deeds towards one's parents, the Buddha, and his disciples,
Such karmic retribution will result in the AvÄ«ci Hell.'
For this reason, my mind is now frightened, and I am in great distress. Moreover, there is no good doctor to save and heal me.
The great minister said again:
I only wish that the great king would not worry.
There are two kinds of Dharma:
First, leaving the household life, and second, the royal Dharma.
The royal Dharma means that if one kills one's father, one becomes king of the country. Although it is said to be a grave offense, in reality there is no crime.
Just as a kalala worm must destroy its mother's womb before it is born, the Dharma of birth is like this. Although it breaks the mother's body, in reality there is no crime.
The same is true for a mule carrying a fetus.
The Dharma of governing the country is like this. Although one kills one's father or elder brother, in reality there is no crime.
As for the Dharma of leaving the household life, even killing a mosquito or ant is a crime.
I only wish that the great king would be magnanimous and not worry.
Why is this?
If one always grieves, grief will only increase;
Just as a person who likes to sleep will sleep more and more,
So it is with greed, lust, and drinking alcohol.
As the king said:
'There is no good doctor in the world to treat the body and mind.'

Now there is a great teacher named Maskarin GoÅ›ÄlÄ«putra, who knows and sees everything, has compassion for sentient beings as if they were his own children, has already freed himself from afflictions, and can pull out the sharp arrows of the three poisons from sentient beings.
All sentient beings have no knowledge, insight, or understanding of all dharmas, but only this one person alone knows, sees, and understands.
Such a great teacher always teaches his disciples in this way:
'The bodies of all sentient beings have seven parts.
What are the seven?
Earth, water, fire, wind, suffering, happiness, and life.
These seven dharmas are not transformed, not created, and cannot be harmed.
Like the iÅ›ika grass, they remain still and unmoving like Mount Sumeru, not abandoning, not creating.
Like milk and curd, they do not argue with each other, whether it is suffering or happiness, good or bad, even if thrown into a sharp knife, it will not cause any harm.'
Why is it so?
Because there is no obstruction in the seven parts of space.
Life also cannot be harmed.
Why is it so?
Because there is no one who harms and no one who dies.
There is no action, no receiver, no speaker, no listener, no one who remembers and no one who teaches.
Always expounding this Dharma, it can cause sentient beings to eliminate all immeasurable grave offenses.
This teacher is now in the great city of RÄjagá¹›ha. I only wish that the great king would go to him.
If the king sees him, all his grave offenses will be extinguished.
At that time, the king replied, If you can truly eliminate my grave offenses like this, I will take refuge.
There was another minister named Siddhi who also went to the king and spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Great king, why is it that
your body is unadorned with necklaces and your hair is disheveled,
to the point of being like this?
Why is the king's body trembling and uneasy, like a flower tree swaying in a fierce wind?
Why is the king's complexion so sorrowful now, like a farmer who has sown seeds but the heavens do not rain, suffering with sorrow like this?
Is it a pain in the heart?
Or a pain in the body?
The king then replied:
How could my body and mind not be in pain now?
My late father, the king, was compassionate and loving, and he had special pity for me, without any real fault.
I once went to ask an astrologer, and the astrologer replied:
'This child, once born, will definitely harm his father.'
Although I heard these words, I still had him raised.
I have heard the wise say:

'If a person has intercourse with his mother or a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, steals the Saá¹ƒgha's property, kills someone who has given rise to the intention for supreme enlightenment, or harms his father, such a person will definitely fall into AvÄ«ci Hell.'
How could my body and mind not be in pain?
The great minister said again:
I only wish that the great king would not worry or be troubled.
If the father king is one who cultivates liberation, then harming him is a crime;
if it is in accordance with the law of governing the country, killing him is not a crime.
Great king!ğŸ”½The non-dharma is called the absence of dharma;
the absence of dharma is called the absence of dharma.
It is like having no children being called having no children;
it is also like having bad children being called having no children, although it is said to be having no children, it is not actually having no children.
It is like food without salt being called having no salt;
if the food has a little salt, it is also called having no salt.
It is like a river without water being called having no water;
if there is a little water, it is also called having no water.
It is like moment-to-moment cessation also being called impermanence;
although abiding for an eon, it is also called impermanence.
It is like a person experiencing suffering being called having no joy;
although experiencing a little joy, it is also called having no joy.
Just as when something is not self-controlled, it is called without self;
Even if it has a little self-control, it is still called without self.
Just as when it is dark at night, it is called without sun;
When there are clouds and mist, it is also said to be without sun.
Great King!
Although it is said that a little dharma is called no dharma, it is not really no dharma.
I wish the king would focus his mind and listen to what I say:
All sentient beings have remaining karma, and because of karmic conditions, they repeatedly experience birth and death.
If the previous king had remaining karma, what crime would the present king have in killing him?
I only wish that the great king would be magnanimous and not grieve.
Why is this?
If one always grieves, grief will eventually increase;
Just as when a person enjoys sleeping, sleep will increase more and more;
Greed, lust, and drinking alcohol are also like this.
As the king said:
'In the world, there is no good doctor to treat the body and mind.'

There is now a great teacher named SaÃ±jayin Vairaá¹­Ä«putra, who knows and sees everything. His wisdom is as deep as the great ocean, he has great authority and great spiritual powers, and can enable sentient beings to be free from doubts and confusion.
All sentient beings do not know, see, or realize, but only this one person alone knows, sees, and realizes.
He is now staying near RÄjagá¹›ha, and for his disciples he teaches the Dharma like this:
Among all the people, if one is a king, one has freedom and can do good or evil at will. Even if one commits many evils, one is still without sin.
Just as fire burns things, whether pure or impure;
The king is also like this, and his nature is the same as fire.
It is like the great earth, which universally supports the pure and the impure. Even if it does this, it is originally without anger or joy;
The king is also like this, and his nature is the same as the earth.
It is like the nature of water, which cleanses the pure and the impure. Even if it does this, it is also without sorrow or joy;
The king is also like this, having the same nature as water.
It is like the nature of wind, which blows both the pure and the impure, and although it does this, it is also without worry or joy;
The king is also like this, having the same nature as wind.
It is like cutting down a tree in autumn, which will grow back in spring, and although it is cut down again, there is actually no fault.
All sentient beings are also like this, passing away here and being reborn here again.
Since they are reborn again, what fault is there?
The results of suffering and happiness for all sentient beings are all not caused by present-life karma, but in the past they caused present-life results;
In the present there is no cause, and in the future there is no result.
Because of present results, sentient beings uphold precepts, diligently cultivate and progress, and block present bad results.
Because of upholding precepts, one attains the undefiled;ğŸ”½Because of attaining the undefiled, defiled karma is exhausted;
Because of exhausting karma, suffering is ended;
Because suffering is ended, one attains liberation.
I only wish that the great king would quickly go to him and have him treat the pain of your body and mind.
If the king sees him, his many sins will be removed.
The king then replied:
If there is such a teacher who can remove my sins, I will take refuge in him.
There was another minister named SarvajÃ±a, who went to the king and said:

Why is the king's appearance not majestic now, like one who has lost his country, like a dried-up spring, a pond without lotus flowers, a tree without flowers or leaves, a monk who has broken the precepts and whose body lacks dignity?
Is it physical pain?
Or is it mental pain?
The king then replied:
How can my body and mind be without pain now?

My father, the late king, was compassionate and caring. However, I am unfilial and do not know how to repay his kindness. He always gave me peace and happiness, but I turned against his kindness and took away his happiness.
The late king was innocent, yet I wantonly committed patricide.
I have also heard the wise say:
'If one harms one's father, one will suffer great torment for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas.
I will soon fall into hell, and there is no good doctor to save me from my crime.'
The great minister then said:
May the great king please put aside your sorrow.
Has the king not heard?
In the past there was a king named Rama who, after killing his father, succeeded to the throne.

King Balti, King VirÅ«á¸haka, King NÄgÄrjuna, King KÄtyÄyana, King ViÅ›Äkha, King Candraprabha, King SÅ«ryaprabha, King PriyadarÅ›ana, and King Bahu-jana, these kings all killed their fathers and succeeded to the throne, yet not a single king entered hell.
In the present, kings such as King VÄ«á¸ura, King Udayana, King Duá¹£prasaha, King Musara, and King Padma all killed their fathers, and none of them had any sorrow.
Although it is said that there are hells, hungry ghosts, and gods, who has seen them?
Great King!
There are only two existences:
First, the human path, and second, the animal realm.
Although there are these two, they are not born due to causes and conditions, nor do they die due to causes and conditions.
If they are not due to causes and conditions, how can there be good and evil?
I only wish that the Great King would not harbor sorrow and fear.
Why is it so?
If one always grieves, grief will only increase;
Just as one who delights in sleep will have more and more sleep;
Greed, lust, and drinking alcohol are also like this.
As the king said:
'In the world there is no good doctor to treat body and mind.'

'There is now a great teacher named Agita Shesha Kumbhira, who knows and sees everything. He views gold and soil as equal and non-dual, cutting his right side with a knife and applying sandalwood to his left, with no difference in his mind towards these two people. He views enemies and friends equally, with no different thoughts in his mind.
This teacher is truly a good doctor in the world. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, he is always in samadhi, his mind without distraction.
He tells his disciples:

'Whether one does it oneself, or instructs others to do it, whether one cuts oneself, or instructs others to cut, whether one burns oneself, or instructs others to burn, whether one harms oneself, or instructs others to harm, whether one steals oneself, or instructs others to steal, whether one commits adultery oneself, or instructs others to commit adultery, whether one lies oneself, or instructs others to lie, whether one drinks alcohol oneself, or instructs others to drink alcohol, whether one kills a village, a city, a country, or kills all beings with a sword wheel, whether one gives to beings south of the Ganges, or kills beings north of the Ganges, there is no sin or merit, no giving, morality, or concentration.'
He is now staying nearby in RÄjagá¹›ha. I wish the king would go quickly.
If the king sees him, all his sins will be eradicated. The king said:
Great minister!ğŸ”½If you can truly eradicate my sins like this, I will take refuge.
Very well!
There was another great minister named Auspicious Virtue who went to the king and said,
Why is your face now without luster, like a lamp in the middle of the day, like the moon at night, like a king who has lost his country, like a ruined land?
Great King!
Now the four directions are peaceful and there are no enemies, so why are you so sorrowful now?
Is it physical suffering?
Or is it mental suffering?
All the princes always have this thought:
'When will I attain self-mastery?'
Great King!

You have now fulfilled your wish and have self-mastery over the country of Magadha. You have obtained the treasure storehouse of the previous king in its entirety. You should just delight in your feelings and enjoy pleasures. Why do you need to be so sorrowful and worried?
The king then replied,
How can I not be sorrowful and distressed now?
Great Minister!
It is like a foolish person who only craves for the taste and does not see the sharp blade;
It is like eating poisoned food without seeing its faults;
I am also like this.
It is like a deer seeing grass but not seeing a deep pit;
It is like a rat greedy for food but not seeing a cat;
I am also like this, seeing present happiness but not seeing the future unpleasant bitter fruits.
I have heard from the wise ones these words:
'It is better to receive three hundred blows in one day than to give rise to a single thought of evil towards one's parents.'
I am now close to the blazing fire of hell, how can I not be sorrowful and distressed?
The great minister said again:
Who came to deceive the king, saying there are hells?
Who created the sharpness of a thorn?
Who created the different colors of flying birds?

The nature of water is to moisten, the nature of stone is to be hard, the nature of wind is to move, and the nature of fire is to be hot. All myriad things die and are born by themselves, who created them?
Speaking of hells is simply the literary creation of the wise ones.
What is the meaning of the word 'hell'?
I shall explain it.
'Di' means earth;
'Lu' means to break.
Breaking through hell, there is no retribution for offenses, this is called hell.
Moreover, 'di' means human;
'lu' means heavenly.
Because of harming one's father, one goes to the human and heavenly realms.
For this reason, the sage Vá¹›ka said:
'Killing sheep brings human and heavenly bliss.'
This is called hell.
Moreover, 'di' means life;
'lu' means long.
Because of taking life, one obtains a long lifespan, thus it is called hell.
Great King!
Therefore, you should know that there truly is no hell.
Great King!
Just as planting wheat gets wheat and planting rice gets rice, killing a hell being gets a hell rebirth, and killing a human should get a human rebirth.
Great King!
Now listen to what I say, there is truly no killing.
If there is a self, there is truly no harm;
If there is no self, there is also nothing to harm.
Why is this?
If there is a self, it is permanent and unchanging;
Because it abides eternally, it cannot be killed, destroyed, bound, or tied up, nor is it angry or happy, just like empty space.
How can there be the sin of killing?
If there is no self, all dharmas are impermanent;
Because of impermanence, they perish moment by moment;
Because they perish moment by moment, both the killer and the killed perish moment by moment.
If they perish moment by moment, who will have the sin?
Great King!ğŸ”½Just as fire burning wood does not have the sin;ğŸ”½Just as an axe chopping a tree is also not sinful;
Just as a sickle cutting grass is truly not sinful.
It is like a knife killing a person. The knife is not really a person. Since the knife is not guilty, how can the person be guilty?
It is like poison killing a person. The poison is not really a person. Since the poison is not guilty, how can the person be guilty?
All myriad things are also like this. There is really no killing. How can there be guilt?
I only wish that the great king would not give rise to sorrow and suffering.
Why is this?
If one always grieves, grief will increase.
It is like a person who delights in sleep. Sleep will increase.
Greed, lust, and drinking alcohol are also like this.
As the king said:
'In the world, there is no good doctor to treat evil karma.'

Now there is a great teacher named KÄla-Buddhi KÄtyÄyana, who knows and sees everything, clearly understands the three times, and in a single thought can see immeasurable and boundless worlds. Hearing sounds is also like this. He can enable sentient beings to stay far away from faults and evil.
Just as the Ganges River, whether inside or outside, purifies all sins,
this great good teacher is also like this, able to remove the many sins inside and outside of sentient beings.
For the disciples, he expounds the Dharma like this:
If a person kills all sentient beings without shame or remorse, they will never fall into evil, just as empty space does not receive dust or water;
Those who are ashamed and remorseful will enter hell, just as great water moistens the earth.
All sentient beings are created by the god MaheÅ›vara. When MaheÅ›vara is pleased, sentient beings are at ease;
When MaheÅ›vara is angry, sentient beings suffer.
The sins and merits of all sentient beings are done by MaheÅ›vara. How can one say that people have sins and merits?
For example, a craftsman makes a wooden person with mechanisms that can walk, stand, sit, and lie down, but can only not speak;
Sentient beings are also like this.
The creator is like a craftsman;
the wooden man is a metaphor for the body of sentient beings.
In this way, who would be guilty of creation?
Such a great teacher is now staying near RÄjagá¹›ha. Please go quickly.
If you see him, all your sins will be extinguished.
The king then replied:
If there is such a person who can extinguish my sins, I will take refuge.
There was another minister named Fearless who went to the king and said these words:
Great King!
In the world, there are foolish people who experience a hundred joys, a hundred sorrows, a hundred sleeps, a hundred awakenings, a hundred fears, and a hundred cries in a single day.
For a wise person, this does not happen.
Great King!

Why are you so sorrowful, like a traveler who has lost his companions, like one fallen into deep mud with no one to pull them out, like a thirsty person who cannot find water to drink, like a confused person without a guide, like a sick person without a doctor to treat them, like a shipwrecked person without anyone to rescue them?
Great King!
Are you in pain now, physically or mentally?
The king then replied:
How could my body and mind not be in pain?
I have befriended evil people and have not considered the consequences of my words. The previous king was innocent, yet I cruelly committed patricide.
I now know for certain that I will enter hell, and there is no good doctor to save me.
The ministers then said:
May the Great King not give rise to sorrow and distress.
The kshatriya are called the royal lineage.
Even if one kills for the sake of the country, for the sake of shramanas and brahmins, or for the sake of bringing peace to the people, there is no sin.
Although the previous king respectfully served the Å›ramaá¹‡as, he was not able to serve the brÄhmaá¹‡as equally, and his mind was not impartial;
Because of this lack of impartiality, he was not a ká¹£atriya.
Great King, you now wish to make offerings to the brÄhmaá¹‡as and kill the previous king. What crime is there in that?
Great King!
In truth, there is no killing.
As for killing, it is killing off life.
Life is called wind and breath.
The nature of wind and breath cannot be killed. How can killing life be a crime?
I only wish that the Great King will not continue to grieve.
Why is this?
If one always grieves, grief will only increase;
It is like a person who enjoys sleeping, sleep will then increase;
Greed, lust, and drinking alcohol are also like this.
As the king said:
'In the world there are no good doctors to treat and cure.'

There is now a great teacher named Nirgrantha JÃ±Ätiputra, who knows and sees everything, has compassion for sentient beings, well understands the sharpness and dullness of sentient beings' faculties, penetrates and understands everything, and skillfully employs expedient means. He is not defiled by the eight worldly dharmas, and peacefully cultivates pure brahmacarya.
He tells his disciples:
There is no giving, no goodness, no father, no mother, no present world, no next world, no arhats, no cultivation, and no path.
All sentient beings, after 80,000 kalpas in the cycle of birth and death, will naturally attain liberation, whether they have offenses or not.
Just as the four great riversâ€”namely, the Sindhu, the Ganges, the Vaká¹£u, and the SÄ«tÄâ€”all enter the great ocean without distinction;
all sentient beings are also like this. When they attain liberation, there is no distinction at all.
That teacher is now staying in RÄjagá¹›ha. May the great king quickly go to him.
If he can see him, his many sins will be eliminated.
The king then replied:
If there is such a teacher who can remove my sins, I will take refuge in him.
At that time, a great physician named JÄ«vaka went to the king and said:
Great king!
Did you sleep peacefully?
The king replied in verse:ğŸ”½If one can permanently sever
all afflictions,
and not be tainted by the three realms, then one can sleep peacefully;
If one attains great nirvÄá¹‡a and expounds the profound meaning,
and is called a true brÄhmaá¹‡a, then one can sleep peacefully;
If one's body is free from evil karma, one's mouth is free from the four faults,
and one's mind is free from doubts and entanglements, then one can sleep peacefully;
If one's body and mind are free from distress and one abides in a tranquil place,
Attaining unsurpassed bliss, one can then sleep peacefully;
The mind is free from attachment, far removed from all enmity,
Always harmonious without dispute, one can then sleep peacefully;
If one does not create evil karma, but always feels shame and remorse,
And believes in the consequences of evil, one can then sleep peacefully;
Respecting and supporting one's parents, not harming the life of a single being,
Not stealing others' wealth, one can then sleep peacefully;
Subduing the senses, befriending good companions,
Destroying the four mÄras, one can then sleep peacefully;
Not seeing auspiciousness or inauspiciousness, nor suffering or happiness,
For the sake of all beings, one cycles in birth and death,
If one is able to do so, one can then sleep peacefully.
Who can sleep peacefully?
Namely, the buddhas are like this, deeply contemplating the samÄdhi of emptiness, body and mind peacefully unmoving.
Who can attain peaceful sleep?
Namely, those with compassion and kindness, always cultivating non-negligence, regarding the multitude as their only child.
Sentient beings are in the darkness of ignorance, not seeing the fruits of afflictions,
Always creating evil karma, unable to attain peaceful sleep;
If it is for one's own body,
Or the bodies of others, creating the ten evil karmas, unable to attain peaceful sleep;
If it is said that for the sake of pleasure, killing one's father is without fault,
Following such evil friends, unable to attain peaceful sleep;
If one's food exceeds moderation, cold drinks are taken to excess,
Thus there is suffering from illness, unable to attain peaceful sleep;
If one has transgressed against the king, or has deviant thoughts towards another's wife,
And those traveling on desolate roads, cannot sleep peacefully;
The fruits of upholding precepts are not yet ripe, the prince has not yet ascended the throne,
And the thief has not yet obtained the wealth, they cannot sleep peacefully.
JÄ«vaka!
I am now gravely ill, having committed a heinous crime against the righteous Dharma king. All skilled physicians, wonderful medicines, spells, skillful nursing, and so forth cannot cure me.
Why is this?
My father, the Dharma king, ruled the country righteously, without any real fault, yet I committed this heinous act.
Like a fish out of water, how can I find joy?
Like a deer in a trap, I have no happy thoughts;
Like a person who knows their life will not last until the end of the day;
Like a king who has lost his country and flees to another land;
Like a person who hears that their illness cannot be cured;
Like one who has broken precepts hears of their faults being spoken.
I once heard the wise say:
'If the actions of body, speech, and mind are impure, one will certainly fall into hell.'
How can I sleep peacefully?
Now I also lack the great doctor of unsurpassed [skill] to expound the Dharma medicine and eliminate my suffering from illness.
JÄ«vaka replied:
Excellent, excellent!
Although the king has committed offenses, he feels heavy remorse and has a sense of shame.
Great King!
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, always speak thus:
'There are two pure dharmas that can save sentient beings:
First, shame; second, remorse.
Shame means not committing offenses oneself;
Remorse means not encouraging others to commit offenses.
Shame means feeling ashamed within oneself;ğŸ”½Remorse means confessing to others.ğŸ”½Shame means feeling embarrassed in front of people;
Remorse means feeling embarrassed in front of the gods.
This is called shame and remorse.
Those without shame and remorse are not called human beings, but are called animals.
Because of having a sense of shame and dishonor, one can respect one's parents and elders;
Because of having a sense of shame and dishonor, one speaks of having parents, brothers, and sisters.
Excellent, great king!
You are fully endowed with a sense of shame and dishonor.
Great king, listen further. I have heard the Buddha say:
'There are two kinds of wise ones:
First, not committing any evil; second, confessing one's misdeeds after committing them.
Fools are also of two kinds:
First, committing offenses; second, concealing them.
Although one may have previously done evil, if one can later confess and repent, feel ashamed and remorseful, and dare not commit them again,
It is like muddy water placed next to a bright pearl, and the water immediately becomes clear due to the pearl's power.
Just as when the smoke and clouds clear away, the moon becomes bright and clear.
Confessing one's misdeeds and repenting is also like this.
If the king confesses and feels ashamed and remorseful, his offenses will be eradicated and he will be pure as before.
